facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 153 of 1960 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 153 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 28, 1960 of Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1243 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 28, 1960, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1243 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on February 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 1.-The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: Magistrate First Class discharged appellants under s. 207A(6) of Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the High Court of Patna, by which an order passed by the Magistrate, First Class, discharging the appellants under s. 207A 6  of the Code of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside Magistrate's discharge order and directed commitment of appellants to Court of Session for trial under ss. 307/34 and 148 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: was set aside, and the Magistrate was directed to commit the appellants to the Court of Session to stand their trial under ss. 307/34 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Assault on Rajbahadur Rai alias Chhote Rai by appellants on March 26, 1959 at about 10-15 p.m. at pan shop of Raghunath Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: On March 26, 1959, at about 10-15 p.m. one Rajbahadur Rai alias Chhote Rai, was alleged to have been assaulted by the appellants at a place where Chhote Rai was sitting, at the pan shop of one Raghunath Prasad.

facts.text: Appellants arrived at scene in a private car and a tandem, assaulted Chhote Rai, and left in those vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are said to have arrived there in a private car and a tandem, and after assaulting Chhote Rai, to have gone away in these two vehicles.

facts.text: Appellants prosecuted under ss. 307/34 and 148 IPC after investigation.

anchor.surface_text: After investigation, the appellants were prosecuted under ss. 307/34 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code, with the result already mentioned.

facts.text: Magistrate heard evidence of nine witnesses including Chhote Rai, Raghunath (FIR informant), Bhushan Singh PW 2, Sheonandan Yadev PW 6.

anchor.surface_text: Before the order of discharge was made, the Magistrate heard the evidence of nine witnesses including Chhote Rai and Raghunath, who had given the first information report. The witnesses also included two other alleged eye-witnesses, Bhushan Singh  P.W. 2 , and Sheonandan Yadev  P.W. 6 .

facts.text: Magistrate conducted spot inspection.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, after recording the evidence and holding a spot inspection and hearing the parties,

facts.text: Magistrate discharged appellants finding prosecution evidence discrepant, unreliable, incredible, highly interested, not worthwhile even for prima facie trial.

anchor.surface_text: discharged the appellants as he was of opinion  in his own words - in view of the aforesaid discrepant, unreliable and incredible and highly interested prosecution evidence, no Court can consider it worthwhile prima facie even for a trial.

facts.text: Magistrate appraised evidence considering credibility of witnesses, antecedents, probabilities, nature of weapon, medical evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate reached this conclusion on a fairly long appraisal of the evidence in the case, discussing it from the angle of credibility of witnesses, their antecedents, the probabilities of the case, the nature of the alleged weapon, the medical evidence and so on.

facts.text: Patna High Court held Magistrate exceeded powers under s. 207A by enquiring beyond commitment stage.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in the order under appeal, held that the Magistrate went beyond the powers conferred upon him of enquiring into the case with a view to committing it to the Court of Session.

facts.text: Section 207A introduced by Code of Criminal Procedure Amendment Act, 1955 (26 of 1955).

anchor.surface_text: Section 207A is a new section, which has been introduced by the Code of Criminal Procedure  Amendment  Act, 1955  26 of 1955 .

facts.text: Supreme Court held Magistrate tried the case instead of assessing prima facie case for commitment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, whatever the jurisdiction conferred by sub-s. 6  of s. 207A, it does not entitle a Magistrate to try the case on his own, and forestall the decision of the Court of Session, and this is what the Magistrate, in fact, did here.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We see no reason to interfere with the order of the High Court, and dismiss the appeal

facts.text: Raghunath Prasad gave the first information report.

anchor.surface_text: including Chhote Rai and Raghunath, who had given the first information report.

facts.text: Bhushan Singh and Sheonandan Yadev are alleged eye-witnesses (PW 2 and PW 6).

anchor.surface_text: The witnesses also included two other alleged eye-witnesses, Bhushan Singh  P.W. 2 , and Sheonandan Yadev  P.W. 6 .

facts.text: Magistrate disbelieved injured person, eye-witnesses, contrasted oral testimony with medical evidence and spot inspection.

anchor.surface_text: In this process, he disbelieved the injured person, other eye-witnesses, contrasted the oral testimony of how the offence took place with the medical evidence and his own conclusions drawn from an inspection of the site and other matters,

facts.text: Case involves delay, hope for day-to-day hearing and expeditious disposal.

anchor.surface_text: It is a matter of regret that much delay has taken place in this case, and it may harm the case or the one side or the other. We hope that now the case will be heard from day to day, and disposed of, as expeditiously as possible.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 28, 1960, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1243 of 1959. Sarjoo Prasad, B.K. Banerjee, P.K. Chatterjee, and A.K. Nag, for the appellants. P. Varma, for the respondent. 1962. February 1.-The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the High Court of Patna, by which an order passed by the Magistrate, First Class, discharging the appellants under s. 207A 6  of the Code of Criminal Procedure,

anchor.surface_text: Sub- section  4  then enjoins upon the Magistrate that he shall proceed to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual commission of the alleged offence, and also enables him to take the evidence of any one or more of the other witnesses for the prosecution as he considers, in his opinion, necessary. The sub-section divides the witnesses into two categories, viz., witnesses to the actual commission of the offence and other witnesses like formal witnesses, or those who cannot depose to the actual commission of the offence. Of the first category, those that the prosecution produces, must be examined but the other witnesses may be examined, only if the Magistrate considers it necessary. It seems, prima facie, that the prosecution cannot insist on their examination. An accused is given by subs.  5  a right to cross-examine the witnesses, who are examined, and the prosecution can also reexamine them. Then comes sub-s  6 , which reads as follows- When the evidence referred to in subsection  4  has been taken and the Magistrate has considered all the documents referred to in sections 173

Mr. Sarjoo Prasad for the appellants, contends, on the basis of the ruling of this Court in Ramgopal Ganpatrai Ruia v. The State of Bombay  1 , that the course followed by the Magistrate in determining whether there was credible evidence or not was the right course, and points to certain passages in the judgment in the above case as supporting his proposition. The cited case interpreted s. 209 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which, after amendment of the Code by Act 26 of 1955, deals with proceedings instituted otherwise than on a police report, and under which the Magistrate can discharge an accused if he finds that there are no sufficient grounds for committing the accused person for trial.

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction conferred by s. 207A(6) CrPC entitles the Magistrate to try the case fully by appraising credibility of witnesses and evidence as if on trial, or only to determine if there is a prima facie case for commitment

anchor.surface_text: Section 207A is a new section, which has been introduced by the Code of Criminal Procedure  Amendment  Act, 1955  26 of 1955 . It lays down the procedure which the Magistrates must follow in an enquiry in proceedings started on a police report, preparatory to companymitment of cases to the Court of Session. Sub-sections  1 ,  2  and  3  deal with the fixing of dates, issuing of processes and ensuring that companyies of the documents referred to is s. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure have been furnished to the accused. Sub- section  4  then enjoins upon the Magistrate that he shall proceed to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual companymission of the alleged offence,

issues.text: Whether the test for discharge under s.207A(6) CrPC is the same as under s.209 CrPC or requires a stronger case against commitment

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarjoo Prasad for the appellants, contends, on the basis of the ruling of this Court in Ramgopal Ganpatrai Ruia v. The State of Bombay  1 , that the course followed by the Magistrate in determining whether there was credible evidence or not was the right course, and points to certain passages in the judgment in the above case as supporting his proposition. The cited case interpreted s. 209 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which, after amendment of the Code by Act 26 of 1955, deals with proceedings instituted otherwise than on a police report, and under which the Magistrate can discharge an accused if he finds that there are no sufficient grounds for committing the accused person for trial.

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section, it is contended, gives the Magistrate the option not to commit an accused but to discharge him, if he is of opinion, for reasons to be recorded, that the evidence discloses no grounds for committing the accused person... The Magistrate... thought that the power conferred upon him by this sub-section enabled him to examine the evidence thoroughly, and if it did not satisfy him, to discharge the accused.

The sub-section divides the witnesses into two categories...

arguments.claim: s.207A(6) does not entitle Magistrate to try the case on his own or forestall Sessions Court; must commit if prima facie case

anchor.surface_text: Put in other words, the section can only mean that if there is a prima facie case triable by the Court of Session, the Magistrate must commit the accused to the Court of session to stand his trial... In our opinion, whatever the jurisdiction conferred by sub-s. 6  of s. 207A, it does not entitle a Magistrate to try the case on his own, and forestall the decision of the Court of Session

arguments.claim: Magistrate disbelieved witnesses, contrasted testimony with medical evidence and spot inspection, effectively tried the case

anchor.surface_text: In this case, we are clear... that he did not stop to find out that there was evidence which, if believed, would establish, at least, a prima facie case but went on further to disbelieve that evidence... In this process, he disbelieved the injured person, other eye-witnesses, contrasted the oral testimony... with the medical evidence and his own conclusions drawn from an inspection of the site

arguments.claim: s.207A requires stronger case for discharge than s.209

anchor.surface_text: The cited case interpreted s. 209... The words of the two sections are not the same... If there is any indication in the language, it is altogether on the side that the Magistrate must find a stronger case for discharging an accused under s. 207A than under s. 209.

holdings.text: Whatever the jurisdiction conferred by sub-s. 6 of s. 207A, it does not entitle a Magistrate to try the case on his own, and forestall the decision of the Court of Session, and this is what the Magistrate, in fact, did here.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, whatever the jurisdiction conferred by sub-s. 6 of s. 207A, it does not entitle a Magistrate to try the case on his own, and forestall the decision of the Court of Session, and this is what the Magistrate, is fact, did here. We, therefore, agree that the order of discharge passed by him was in excess of his jurisdiction, and it is hardly necessary in this case to show how far a Magistrate can go to find that there is numberground for companymitting the accused to stand his trial in a Court of Session.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual interpretation of s.207A as procedure for preliminary inquiry preparatory to commitment, not a mini-trial; Magistrate's detailed credibility assessment and disbelief of evidence exceeds scope.

holdings.text: The order of discharge passed by the Magistrate was in excess of his jurisdiction under s.207A(6).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree that the order of discharge passed by him was in excess of his jurisdiction, and it is hardly necessary in this case to show how far a Magistrate can go to find that there is numberground for companymitting the accused to stand his trial in a Court of Session. We see numberreason to interfere with the order of the High Court, and dismiss the appeal It is a matter of regret that much delay has taken place in this case,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate conducted full appraisal of credibility, antecedents, probabilities, medical evidence, spot inspection, disbelieved witnesses instead of checking for prima facie case existence.

holdings.text: The section can only mean that if there is a prima facie case triable by the Court of Session, the Magistrate must commit the accused to the Court of Session to stand his trial.

anchor.surface_text: To this extent, Mr. Sarjoo Prasad fairly companycedes, s. 207A  6  cannot be carried. Put in other words, the section can only mean that if there is a prima facia case triable by the Court of Session, the Magistrate must companymit the accused to the Court of session to stand his trial. What those cases would be, which would satisfy the test, may number generally be stated here, because, in our opinion, this case is far from the borderline, where only difficulties are likely to be met.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of sub-s.(6): discharge only if evidence discloses no grounds for commitment; prima facie case exists if evidence, if believed, establishes offence triable by Sessions Court.

holdings.text: The Magistrate must find a stronger case for discharging an accused under s. 207A than under s. 209.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the two sections are number the same, and it is possible to say that the force of the two sections is also number the same, and that s. 209 gives a power to enter upon the merits of a case in a manner which s. 207A does number warrant. Whether the change of the language is deliberate or due to the fact that different draftsmen drafted the two sections, the test for discharging the accused must, in a large way. be the same under both the sections, and it is hardly necessary to decide the full of ambit of s. 207A and companytrast it with that of s. 209. If there is any indication in the language, it is altogether on the side that the Magistrate must find a stronger case for discharging an accused under s. 207A than under s. 209.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comparative textual analysis shows different wording; s.207A (police report cases) demands higher threshold for discharge than s.209 (non-police cases).

holdings.text: There is no reason to interfere with the order of the High Court, and the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberreason to interfere with the order of the High Court, and dismiss the appeal It is a matter of regret that much delay has taken place in this case, and it may harm the case or the one side or the other. We hope that number the case will be heard from day to day, and disposed of, as expeditiously as possible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held Magistrate exceeded jurisdiction; appellants fail to show proper exercise of power under s.207A(6).

edges.explanation: The holding interprets 'the section' (s.207A) to require the Magistrate to commit the accused to the Court of Session if there is a prima facie case triable there, directly addressing whether the Magistrate's jurisdiction under s.207A(6) allows full trial or only commitment/discharge.

anchor.surface_text: To this extent, Mr. Sarjoo Prasad fairly companycedes, s. 207A  6  cannot be carried. Put in other words, the section can only mean that if there is a prima facia case triable by the Court of Session, the Magistrate must companymit the accused to the Court of session to stand his trial. What those cases would be, which would satisfy the test, may number generally be stated here, because, in our opinion, this case is far from the borderline, where only difficulties are likely to be met.

edges.explanation: h4 constrains application of c2 by requiring stronger case for discharge under s. 207A
h4 specifies stronger case needed for discharge under s. 207A than s. 209, directly addressing i3

anchor.surface_text: The words of the two sections are number the same, and it is possible to say that the force of the two sections is also number the same, and that s. 209 gives a power to enter upon the merits of a case in a manner which s. 207A does number warrant. Whether the change of the language is deliberate or due to the fact that different draftsmen drafted the two sections, the test for discharging the accused must, in a large way. be the same under both the sections, and it is hardly necessary to decide the full of ambit of s. 207A and companytrast it with that of s. 209. If there is any indication in the language, it is altogether on the side that the Magistrate must find a stronger case for discharging an accused under s. 207A than under s. 209.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 supports h2 by refusing to interfere with the High Court, which aligns with and upholds the finding that the Magistrate exceeded jurisdiction under s.207A(6).
